questions.question: Which UNESCO site in Cambodia is renowned for its impressive temple complex that was built in the early 12th century and is featured on the national flag?
questions.context: Constructed as a Hindu temple dedicated to Vishnu, it transitioned into a Buddhist temple towards the end of the 12th century.

questions.question: Located in the southeastern part of Australia, which UNESCO site is known for its distinctive sandstone monolith and is sacred to the Indigenous Anangu people?
questions.context: This massive rock formation stands 348 meters high and is a key feature of the Northern Territory landscape.

questions.question: Which UNESCO site in France, known for its beautiful Gothic architecture, hosted the coronation of numerous French kings from 1027 to 1825?
questions.context: This cathedral is celebrated for its stunning stained-glass windows and a monumental fa√ßade.

questions.question: Which UNESCO site in South Africa is recognized for its ancient hominid fossils, earning it the nickname 'Cradle of Humankind'?
questions.context: This site has yielded some of the most significant early hominid fossils that provide insight into human evolution.

questions.question: In Italy, what UNESCO site is famous for its well-preserved ruins buried by a volcanic eruption in AD 79 and provides insight into Roman life?
questions.context: This ancient city was buried by ash and pumice from the eruption of Mount Vesuvius.
